data.title: Solana (SOL) Upside Builds, $100 Breakout Hopes Strengthen Across Market
data.description:
Solana started a fresh increase above the $82 zone. SOL price is now consolidating above $85 and might aim for more gains above the $95 zone.

  • SOL price started a fresh upward move above the $82 and $85 levels against the US Dollar.
  • The price is now trading above $82 and the 100-hourly simple moving average.
  • There was a break above a bearish trend line with resistance at $87 on the hourly chart of the SOL/USD pair (data source from Kraken).
  • The pair could extend gains if it clears the $88 resistance zone.

Solana Price Regains Traction

Solana price started a decent increase after it settled above the $82 zone, like Bitcoin and Ethereum. SOL climbed above the $85 level to enter a short-term positive zone.

The price even smashed the $88 resistance. The bulls were able to push the price above $90. A high was formed at $92, and the price is now consolidating gains. There was a minor decline below the 23.6% Fib retracement level of the recent upward move from the $75.64 swing low to the $92.05 high.

Recently, there was a break above a bearish trend line with resistance at $87 on the hourly chart of the SOL/USD pair. Solana is now trading above $85 and the 100-hourly simple moving average.

On the upside, the price is facing resistance near $88. The next major resistance is near the $92 level. The main resistance could be $95. A successful close above the $95 resistance zone could set the pace for another steady increase. The next key resistance is $100. Any more gains might send the price toward the $106 level.

Downside Correction In SOL?

If SOL fails to rise above the $88 resistance, it could start another decline. Initial support on the downside is near the $85.50 zone. The first major support is near the $84 level or the 50% Fib retracement level of the recent upward move from the $75.64 swing low to the $92.05 high.

A break below the $84 level might send the price toward the $82 support zone. If there is a close below the $82 support, the price could decline toward the $78 support in the near term.

Technical Indicators

Hourly MACD – The MACD for SOL/USD is gaining pace in the bullish zone.

Hourly Hours RSI (Relative Strength Index) – The RSI for SOL/USD is above the 50 level.

Major Support Levels – $85.50 and $84.00

Major Resistance Levels – $88 and $95.

data.title: Warden (WARD) - The Inference Ep. 14 - 27 February 2026
data.description:
According to the Warden Protocol X announcement, Episode 14 of “The Inference” will run live on X and YouTube at 10:00 UTC on 27 February 2026, continuing its Friday show format with core contributors and guests discussing the project and ecosystem developments (source). Mechanically, this is a recurring communication and transparency event rather than a direct tokenomic change. For traders, the main relevance is its potential as a venue for roadmap updates, product progress, or partnership news, which can shift sentiment and intraday volatility if new information about WARD’s future utility or timelines is disclosed.

Warden
@wardenprotocol

As every Friday, join @yulikay, @luisvae, and @JoshGoodbody for the best moment of the week: "The Inference".

Already Episode 14!

️ 27.02.26

10 AM UTC

Live on X and YouTube

Set a reminder! pic.twitter.com/8atKbekjEX

Feb 26, 2026

data.title: Holo (HOT) - Weekly Support Call - 27 February 2026
data.description:
Holo will host a Weekly Edge Node Support Call each Friday, providing live chat-based troubleshooting and Q&A for node operators, as outlined in the project’s X update announcing the shift in technical support model while they “race toward [their] next major delivery milestones” (source). Mechanically, these calls are operational: they help operators maintain and upgrade Edge Nodes, reducing friction and downtime. Healthier node participation can improve network reliability and capacity, which underpins the fundamental utility of Holo. For HOT traders, the cadence and content of these calls serve as a recurring, real-time signal of development progress and ecosystem readiness.

Holo
@H_O_L_O_

To build faster, we have to streamline our focus. ️

As we race toward our next major delivery milestones, we are shifting our technical support model. Starting tomorrow, we will be hosting a Weekly Edge Node Support Call every Friday.

Bring your questions, drop them in the…

Feb 26, 2026

data.title: Creditlink Token (CDL) - Bi-Weekly Voice Room - 27 February 2026
data.description:
Creditlink is holding a bi-weekly Voice Room at 12:00 UTC on 27 February 2026, with small USDT rewards for social engagement and questions, as detailed in the project’s X post promoting the session and its participation tasks and prizes (source). Mechanically, this is a community AMA and engagement event on Discord, not a protocol or tokenomic change. The main price relevance is indirect: such sessions can be used to communicate roadmap updates, clarify product progress, and attract new users. Short-term, marketing plus giveaways can increase attention and speculative trading in CDL if messaging resonates with participants.

data.title: Lynas Rare Earths' Departing CEO Has Sights on Pentagon Supply Deal — Interview
data.description:
By Rhiannon Hoyle

The chief executive of Lynas Rare Earths hopes to find an agreement with the Pentagon on rare-earths supply before she steps down at the end of June, and said that plans for a new processing plant in Texas will remain stalled until those talks are finalized.

Amanda Lacaze also tentatively praised the Trump administration's planned $12 billion critical minerals stockpile, called Project Vault, although she said it is unclear how Lynas might participate, adding that details remain limited.

Lynas, which has a market value of roughly $12 billion, has expanded its operations in recent years, betting on rising demand for non-Chinese supply of rare earths. Outside of China, it is the largest producer of separated light rare earths and the only commercial producer of heavy rare earths.

Last year, the Australian company raised capital to speed up its expansion. Lacaze said the rare-earths market is evolving rapidly and that Lynas must move quickly to make the most of its existing business and to add to it.

At the time, Lynas cautioned that a planned heavy rare-earths processing facility in Texas might not go ahead, and that it was in talks with the Defense Department to negotiate a "mutually acceptable offtake agreement" from its existing operations.

Speaking in an interview, Lacaze said that discussions with the Defense Department about supply are continuing, but that she hopes "that we are able to do something" before she retires from Lynas at the end of June after 12 years at the helm.

The future of the Seadrift, Texas heavy rare-earths project--which was allocated roughly $258 million in grant funding by the Defense Department in 2023--remains unclear, she said.

"Nothing will move until we've resolved all matters with the DoW," or Department of War, said Lacaze, referring to the unofficial name that the Pentagon has revived for the Defense Department.

Lynas today processes its rare earths at a plant in Malaysia. It has built a new production line that last year produced the first dysprosium and terbium available commercially outside of China in decades.

In October, it announced plans to expand its heavy rare-earths output, prioritizing samarium--needed for magnets in defense technologies, such as F-35 jet fighters--before adding other products.

That expansion could supplant Lynas's plans for the new facility in Texas.

Lacaze said it makes more financial sense to expand the company's existing operations than to build a small, new plant in the U.S.

"The economics are just fundamentally different," she said. "The fact that we've announced the investment in Malaysia and the heavy rare-earths plant, I think, tells you where our position is on this."

In a move to make its brand better known in the U.S., Lynas ran an advertising campaign in Washington in November and December that included digital billboards at Washington Dulles International Airport and Union Station. Running ads isn't common among miners, who sell their products to processors, manufacturers and traders.

Lacaze, who has a background in marketing, said Lynas wanted to address rising concerns about the availability of rare-earths supply in the West. Fears were stoked by export restrictions in China, which supplies most of the world's rare earths today.

"It was really about brand, about brand recognition and about driving home that message that we actually have product available," she said.

Lynas on Thursday reported a sharp jump in first-half net profit, fueled by higher sales and rare-earths prices. By midafternoon in Sydney on Friday, shares in Lynas were roughly 19% higher on the start of the week.

Seeking to address concerns about future shortages, the Trump administration on Feb. 2 announced plans for the $12 billion Project Vault stockpile of critical minerals.

"I think that it's valuable because it forms part of this whole complex of policies that various governments are putting in place to really address market dysfunction," said Lacaze. "And once the market dysfunction is addressed, then a lot of the other issues in the market just melt away."

Yet it remains unclear exactly how the stockpile will work, Lacaze said. Lynas is similarly unsure about how a planned roughly $800 million critical mineral strategic reserve in Australia will operate.

"I think that we're all in the industry waiting to see exactly how it might work and what might be in the vault because, frankly, you can't put magnets in the vault, because they're not a standard," she said.

Lacaze said Lynas will continue to negotiate commercial agreements directly with customers. "But that's not to say that we wouldn't participate in one or other of these types of programs if we see that it is both beneficial for us and also for the industry," she said. "A robust industry is good for all of us."

Write to Rhiannon Hoyle at rhiannon.hoyle@wsj.com

data.title: Embarrassing defeat for UK's Starmer as Greens seize Labour stronghold
data.description:
Key points:
  • Defeat boosts pressure on unpopular PM Starmer
  • Labour pushed into third place in previously safe seat
  • Green Party win first parliamentary by-election
  • Result highlights fracturing of British politics

By Andy Bruce and Andrew MacAskill

Prime Minister Keir Starmer's Labour Party suffered an embarrassing election defeat on Friday in an area of Greater Manchester that it had dominated for almost a century, a loss that underscores the breakdown of Britain's two-party politics.

The loss of one of Labour's safest seats, in the biggest electoral test in almost a year, puts further pressure on Starmer to prove that he should keep his job following weeks of political turmoil and calls for him to resign.

The left-wing Green Party's Hannah Spencer won the contest for the vacant parliamentary seat of Gorton and Denton, with Nigel Farage's anti-immigration Reform UK party coming second, and Labour pushed into third place.

The result was "clearly disappointing", said Labour party chair Anna Turley.

Starmer had staked his personal authority on Labour winning the seat by blocking one of his rivals, the popular Manchester mayor Andy Burnham, from standing, and by visiting the constituency this week when British leaders normally avoid campaigning in local areas if they risk losing.

The defeat comes after Starmer faced the most dangerous moment of his premiership this month when some of his lawmakers said he should resign over his decision to appoint Labour veteran Peter Mandelson as ambassador to Washington, despite his links to the late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.

DEFEAT PILES PRESSURE ON STARMER BEFORE MAY ELECTIONS

Labour won just over half the vote in Gorton and Denton at the last general election in 2024. But Starmer's unpopularity, sluggish economic growth and a series of scandals and policy U-turns contributed to a deep fall in the party's support.

The Green Party won 40.7% of the vote on Friday in an election triggered when a member of parliament resigned for health reasons. Nigel Farage's Reform Party came second with 28.7% of the votes and Labour finished third with 25.4%.

Starmer was unlikely to face an immediate threat to his position if he lost, Labour lawmakers said before the vote.

But he could be challenged after May elections, they added, when Labour is expected to fare badly in local and regional polls, including for the parliaments in Wales and Scotland.

It was the first time the Green Party, which supports leaving NATO and legalising recreational drugs, had won a one-off election for a seat in parliament or one in the north of England.

That takes the party's total number of seats in the House of Commons to five out of 650.
